content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

From the thumbnail, I see multiple fragments of tissue, most of which appear to be adipose (fatty) tissue. Embedded within these fragments are several discrete, more basophilic (dark purple) nodules of varying sizes. These nodules are characteristic of lymph nodes. My initial impression is that this is a lymph node dissection specimen, and my primary task would be to systematically examine each of these nodules for evidence of metastatic cancer.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

The area indicated by the green box is a well-circumscribed, basophilic nodule located in the central tissue fragment. This morphology at low power is highly suggestive of a lymph node. As part of the cancer staging process, it is crucial to examine every lymph node for the presence of tumor cells. I am zooming into this specific nodule to assess its architecture and cellular composition at higher magnification to determine if it contains metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area on the first large tissue fragment from the left because it shows an abnormal structure. There is a thick-walled, vessel-like or cystic structure with associated basophilic cellular material lining its inner surface. This appearance is highly suspicious for extramural venous invasion (EMVI), where a large vein is invaded by tumor. It is critical to examine this at high power to confirm the presence of tumor cells within a vessel, as EMVI is a major prognostic factor in colorectal cancer. Alternatively, it could be a necrotic lymph node metastasis with a fibrotic capsule, which also requires closer evaluation. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I see a portion of a lymph node being infiltrated by malignant glands. On the left, there are large, irregular, back-to-back glandular structures lined by atypical epithelial cells with hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei. Some glands contain necrotic debris in their lumens. These features are characteristic of adenocarcinoma. The tumor is surrounded by a rim of residual lymphoid tissue and then by the perinodal adipose tissue on the right. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, containing metastatic adenocarcinoma consistent with a colorectal primary.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see the wall of a large-caliber blood vessel, most likely a vein, which is thickened and hyalinized (dense pink, acellular appearance). Lining the inner aspect of this vessel wall is a cluster of malignant epithelial cells, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. These tumor cells show pleomorphic nuclei, are arranged in irregular nests, and are associated with necrotic debris and hemorrhage within the vessel lumen. My impression is that this is a clear-cut case of large vessel extramural venous invasion (EMVI) by adenocarcinoma.
